steps.p: We are speeding on a highway to CO₂ hell…
… and we need to slow down. because it's already too late.
The red smoke filling up on your left is how much CO₂ we have emitted into the atmosphere since 1850. The more heat gets trapped, the hotter our planet gets - and this isn't good.
Human activity has been increasing the amount of CO₂ mostly since the industrial revolution in the early 1800s and...
… we are pouring more out and faster than ever before.

By current estimates, we have emitted about 2,200 gigatonnes of CO₂ in the atmosphere - and there is some uncertainty around this exact amount which we've tried to represent with the amount of smoke you see.
That means, we are already at almost 1ºC of global warming which is already super bad for our planet.
Where has all that CO₂ come from? We have been counting since 1990:
Although, no matter how you count it and divide it, what we have emitted remains emitted. At the current speed, global warming will reach 1.5 ºC by 2040. We need to slow this down.

text.p: The bar below represents the remaining carbon budget.
Try to slow it down before we reach the carbon limit by trying out some of the emission reduction options below.

data.p: Historical time series: Global cumulative CO2 emissions including fossil fuels and industry plus land-use change emissions from Global Carbon Project until 2017. Unit change from C toCO2. After 2017 we add a constant annual emissions of 17 Gt CO2
Remaining carbon budget and related uncertainty: as reported in IPCC, 2018: Global Warming of 1.5°C.
Partition of global accumulated emissions 1990-2017: Our World in Data
Partition of global emissions by sectors: Our World in Data
Eat less meat. Sources: FAO, Options for keeping the food system within environmental limits, Nature, IPCC
Increase renewable energy. Source: International Renewable Energy Agency 2017 report

Restore and protect forests and wetlands. Sources: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America Report 2017, Sectoral greenhouse gas emission reduction potential in 2030 by UNEP

disclaimer.p: The current version is  a proof of concept. For a thorough analysis of global warming and mitigation possibilities we refer the user to the original sources of information.
